>no GF, so you don't have to justify eating ramen one night, just because, and whipping up a multi-course meal the next
>tonight, you went for simple, then toss several large boxes on the carport
>eventually you'll enclose it into a full garage, but there's other things to take care of first
>your whole-house mancave will take weeks to look like home, but today was a good start
>the living room has a bunch of vintage hifi speakers ready to blast tunes out of gloriously oiled woodgrain

>the rest of the electronics are in boxes
>tomorrow, you think, is Saturday
>perfect for getting things connected
>clothes go in the hamper, everything except your boxers
>you fall asleep easy, but wake up to noise in the backyard
>probably just some raccoon or possum from the woods, you think
>there's not even a garbage can out there, and they can't eat cardboard
>a flash outside is followed by a thunderclap, and the staccato of rain
>you let the noise lull you back towards dreaming
>a few minutes later you realize whatever got in the backyard is making more noise, now sheltering in the carport
>it can stay there all night for all you care
>its movement keeps you awake
>you get up, scratching your belly and wondering if some warm milk and a sandwich will help

Anonymous Mon 02 Nov 2020 05:35:34 No.33793859 Report
Quoted By: >>33794019 >>33794180 >>33795344 >>33810346 >>33810390
Why does browsing this place cause so much heartache.
Y'all write characters with flaws and that makes it hurt so much more.
Why?
Anonymous
  • Post
  • Report

Anonymous Mon 02 Nov 2020 05:42:54 No.33794019 Report
Quoted By: >>33794765
>>33793859
Meredithfag here. In my amateur opinion, it's because it makes the characters feel human; we see ourselves fucking up in their stead, succeeding where they do, and ultimately it makes the ending of the story-happy or otherwise- all the more painful to read.

I suffer from severe depression, and it has a tendency to show up in my other writing as well. The setting is always bleak, but with a little bit of hope coming through in the end. The characters, flawed just as much as you or I, but still standing tall in spite of it; we put ourselves in our writing so that you, the reader, can more easily relate to the characters and scenarios within.

Hope that clears it up for you.
Anonymous

  • Report

Anonymous Tue 03 Nov 2020 02:37:17 No.33814228 Report
Quoted By: >>33814350 >>33814677
>>33813977
I'm trying to be as objective as I can here given that I don't know anything about the characters and setting: unless this is some kind of prologue, I'd redo it. PURELY because it pretty immediately launches into stream-of-consciousness that borders on exposition, and my eyes glaze over when people try to show me scifi or fantasy that starts with boring exposition.

Best writing advice I ever got? Drop your character (reader) right in the middle of the action and go from there. I've seen so, so, so, so many stories outright rejected because the author has to set things up without moving characters around in a defined scene.

See this line?

>As the distinct keening of the Swarm Rack preparing another salvo fills the air, you grip your wife's hand tightly, with her following suit.

This is the very first time I could actually picture in my mind's eye what's going on -- and without that mental theater, you have a textbook, not a story. I feel like I'm unqualified to read everything prior to this point because I don't know (or care) about the lore.

If I had ANY advice for overcoming this sort of thing, it's to SHOW and not TELL, unless you're certain you can get away with it.

For example:
>One hellish moment of psionic and radio distortion later, and you knew, just knew, that you weren't going to walk out of this in one piece.

What does this sound like? Is it like knives scraping against plates? Is it an overpowering voice chanting in your head? Does our hero fall to the ground in agony while his intrepid waifur helps him to his feet? What does the dirt/whatever feel like beneath his boots? Put me in the scene with the character. Pretend you're a camera and you're filming a scene and then describe what you see.

Again, I'm trying to not come off as a dick, so I preemptively apologize if I come off that way.
Anonymous

  • Report

Anonymous Tue 03 Nov 2020 02:52:10 No.33814561 Report
Quoted By:
>>33814350
>While I do try for 'Show, don't tell', the only issue I have with this is that Caves of Qud isn't exactly well known; it's hard for me to really translate it into something that other readers would be able to grasp.

True, but I'll counter with this: nobody knows anything about anyone's lore until they make them care about it. Trust me, I've dealt with this in my own work 1000000000 times, as well as all the work I've edited in my time. One method I find useful is to use the original Star Wars trilogy as an example. Love or hate it, the point is, we (the audience) know exactly as much about The Force as we need to in order for the plot to happen. Apply the same logic to your exposition.

Floating city? Cool, our heroes need to grapple on to it. They can learn about why it's floating as they find out it's now crashing to the ground with 50,000 people onboard.

Great old tree at the center of town? It's dying and is releasing toxic fumes, killing dozens as it progresses through the town. Our heroes will learn about its death as they uncover the dark blade freshly embedded in the tree's trunk.

Hero gets blasted by a psionic screech? It knocks him on his ass and delays his knick-of-time rescue of his waifur or something.

FUNCTIONAL lore/exposition. That's what I'm preaching. Every writing teacher/professor/coach I've ever had has beaten this solidly into my head. There are so few times when exposition is warranted and welcomed by the reader, and that's to answer questions posed by the plot + its characters. And even then, avoid just telling the reader what they need to know. You can do this man. I believe in you.

>I'll take your advice in stride, and I'll be sure to keep it in mind for when I do start to write. It'll be slow, but it'll get done.
God speed Anon. I 100% believe in you.

Anonymous Tue 03 Nov 2020 02:57:24 No.33814677 Report

>>33814228
>What does this...
Not everything needs to be described, in my opinion. To use your camera analogy, it's all about varying things between tighter and wider shots, and how you frame it. But if you can't look at a paragraph you've written and know what isn't scribbled down - and why it isn't needed - then maybe things are too flat.

It all comes down to where the skill balance is for a given writer between dialogue and narration/exposition. Whatever paints the scene , works.

Anonymous Tue 03 Nov 2020 03:03:09 No.33814823 Report
Quoted By: >>33815063
>>33814677
>Not everything needs to be described, in my opinion
No, you're right. It needs variance. Don't waste the reader's time. All I'm asking for is to be put in an interesting and engaging scene and be made to feel what something is supposed to look like.

When I say "describe how the dirt/whatever feels under his boots" I guess I'm saying do it if it helps him remember the 20,000 buried beneath him.

I'm asking to be put into a scene. A really good writing exercise I try to practice is to write:
>What is the room I'm standing in? What are its basic properties?
>What does it smell like?
>What does it feel like?
>What does it taste like?
>How does it feel to me?
>What's in here and why is that important? What am I doing with it?

All from the perspective of a man who has just lost his child, or something like that. Because we, as writers, are obligated to write slanted. Write a rescue from the perspective of a cowawrd. Write a murder from the perspective of a pascifst.

Anonymous Tue 03 Nov 2020 03:14:21 No.33815063 Report
Quoted By: >>33815352
>>33814823
>A really good writing exercise
So true.
Since I tend to start with dialogue, one of the key things I need to do as I build a scene is understand their motivations & personality. What comes out of their mouth is a "slanted" reflection of their thoughts. How they interact with each other, and how their environment colors their internal thoughts, is another aspect of that.
But all of this depends further on what tense & POV you're writing from. None of us are perfect, so each scene is us practicing the skills we're talking about as well as pushing our current limits.
